snippet: Machine learning algorithms can automatically improve their performance through experience. This capability distinguishes ML from traditional programming approaches where explicit instructions must be provided for every scenario.

Neural networks mimic the structure of biological neurons, creating artificial neural pathways that can process complex patterns in data. The interconnected nature allows for distributed processing and learning.
Supervised learning requires labeled training data to build predictive models. The algorithm learns from input-output pairs to generalize patterns for making predictions on new, unseen data.
Statistical learning theory provides the mathematical foundation for machine learning algorithms. It establishes bounds on generalization error and guides algorithm design for optimal performance.
